Author: emccue
Content: conceptually an array is not a good fit for continual appending

Author: emccue
Content: If you want to do an operation like that you would be best off writing or finding your own "ArrayList" kind of wrapper

Author: MemoryError
Content: is there a way to find the index of the last item in the list

Author: MemoryError
Content: array*

Author: emccue
Content: I think you don't quite understand what an array in c _is_

Author: emccue
Content: it is a fixed size block of memory

Author: emccue
Content: that you have a pointer to the start of

Author: emccue
Content: it is up to you to keep track of the size of that array

Author: emccue
Content: usually in a seperate int

Author: emccue
Content: because you only have the pointer to the start of the block of memory

Author: emccue
Content: nothing about that pointer can tell you how much memory ahead of that you are allowed to access

Author: emccue
Content: so if you keep the size of the array and the pointer to the start of the array held somewhere then the "index of the last item" is something you implicitly know

Author: emccue
Content: and I might be wrong when I say to store it in an int

Author: emccue
Content: it might be a `usize` or some other type

Author: emccue
Content: ```rustNLuse rusqlite::{Connection_ NO_PARAMS};NLNL#[derive(Debug)]NLstruct Entry {NL    id: i64_NL    title: String_NL    content: StringNL}NLNLfn insert_entry(conn: &Connection_ entry: &Entry) -> rusqlite::Result<usize> {NL    conn.execute("\NL    INSERT INTO Entries (Title_ Content)NL        VALUES (?1_ ?2)NL    "_NL    &[&entry.title_ &entry.content])NL}NLNLfn all_entries(conn: &Connection) -> rusqlite::Result<Vec<Entry>> {NL    let mut stmt = connNL        .prepare("SELECT ID_ Title_ Content FROM Entries")?;NL    let entry_iter = stmt.query_map(NL        NO_PARAMS_NL        |row| Ok(Entry{NL            id: row.get(0)?_NL            title: row.get(1)?_NL            content: row.get(2)?NL        })NL    )?;NLNL    let mut entries = Vec::new();NL    for entry in entry_iter {NL        entries.push(entry?);NL    }NLNL    Ok(entries)NL}NLNLfn main() -> rusqlite::Result<()> {NL    let conn = Connection::open("db.sqlite")?;NL    conn.execute("\NL    CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS Entries(NL              ID INTEGER PRIMARY KEY_NL              Title CHAR(512)_NL              Content TEXT);NL    "_NL    NO_PARAMS)?;NLNL    let entry_1 = Entry {NL        id: 0_NL        title: String::from("Entry Number One")_NL        content: String::from("This is the text for my entry.")NL    };NLNL    let entry_2 = Entry {NL        id: 1_NL        title: String::from("Le Second Entreee")_NL        content: String::from("2. What is 2? Can you taste it?")NL    };NLNL    insert_entry(&conn_&entry_1)?;NL    insert_entry(&conn_&entry_2)?;NLNLNLNL    println!("{:?}"_ all_entries(&conn));NLNL    Ok(())NL}NL```

Author: Anti
Content: I've been doodling around with making my own compiler today.

Author: Anti
Content: I decided not to tokenize all of the characters and digits in identifiers and numeric literals 'cause I kinda don't have to?

Author: Anti
Content: And going out of my way to do that makes a lot more work to put those things back together properly later.

Author: Anti
Content: A side effect is I get to do this:

Author: Anti
Content: ```NL0xafe_starts_with_a_number :int = 0xafe;```

Author: Anti
Content: Tokenizer's output:

Author: Anti
Content: ```NLLine:                        Token:                   Token Type:NL00001    0xafe_starts_with_a_number                  ALPHANUMERICNL00001                             :                   TYPE_MARKERNL00001                           int                  ALPHANUMERICNL00001                             =                    ASSIGNMENTNL00001                         0xafe           HEXADECIMAL_LITERALNL00001                             ;                   END_OF_LINE```

Author: Anti
Content: My thinking is I can define numbers in the grammar in such a way that the parser looks for BINARY_LITERAL_ HEXADECIMAL_LITERAL_ or DECIMAL_LITERAL tokens instead of caring about the contents of the tokens.

Author: Anti
Content: 'Cause the lexer already ensures those will be put together and tagged properly.

Author: somebody
Content: <@326422614073671681> why would the parser care about the contents

Author: somebody
Content: if you mean the lexer outputting `BINARY_LITERAL` instead of the parser figuring which one it is then that's done very_ _very_ often
